Organs/Tissues: Any organ model (gut, brain, lung, liver, kidney, etc.)—the system is chip-agnostic, used with partner chips
Physiological/Pathological: Both. Enables normal physiological flow conditions or disease simulations (inflammatory stimuli, infection, drug toxicity)
Cell Source: Compatible with cell lines (e.g. Caco-2, b.End3) and primary/iPSC-derived cells (for advanced 3D tissues or organoids)
Multiple Cell Types: Yes (co-culture across compartments, e.g. epithelium-endothelium, immune-tissue, etc.)
Stromal Cells: Yes (fibroblasts, pericytes in co-culture, embedded in 3D hydrogels)
Tissue-resident Immune: Yes (macrophages, microglia, etc.), included in organ-specific compartments
Circulating Immune: Yes (neutrophils, lymphocytes can be perfused through vascular channels)
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Yes, can connect multiple chips or multi-chamber chips to study organ-organ interactions
Air-Liquid Interface: Supported by partner chips (e.g. BE-Transflow), enabling lung/skin ALI cultures
Extracellular Matrix: Yes (hydrogels, collagen, Matrigel). Flow is gentle, preserving 3D ECM structures
3D Scaffold: Yes. Spheroids, organoids, or tissue slices can be perfused in partner chips (e.g. 3D Beonchip devices)
Notable Features: Precise pressure-based flow control. Pulsation-free. Automated media switching. Real-time flow sensors. Long-term stable perfusion
Plate/Format (Throughput): Individual chips, typically 1–4 channels per device. Medium throughput by parallelizing multiple chips
Max Culture Duration: Days to weeks of continuous perfusion. System stable for extended runs
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes (chips are transparent). System can be placed on microscope. Battery or modular design for easy imaging
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes. Automated effluent collection for biomarker assays
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Possible by enzymatic flush. Typically imaging or in situ analysis is done
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Difficult, depends on chip design. Often in situ histology. Some chips are openable for 3D constructs
Readouts - TEER: Not integrated, but feasible with external electrodes or partner chip solutions
Readouts - MEA: No built-in. Could integrate external MEA chip if needed
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: No default chemical sensors. External or custom integration possible
Dead Volume: Minimal (small-bore tubing, microfluidic channels). Rapid response to flow switches
Perfused: Core feature: continuous, stable flow with real-time control. Pulsation-free pressure pumping
Gas Mix Controlled: Via incubator or external source. System placed in or adjacent to an incubator
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Yes, automated flow profiles, dynamic stimulus injection, gradient generation
model_availability: Commercial product. Users buy hardware & partner chips, supply own cells

Organs/Tissues: Universal for multiple organ models (gut, liver, cancer, kidney, etc.) in single microfluidic chips
Physiological/Pathological: Both. Allows healthy tissue conditions or disease stimuli (infection, hypoxia, drug exposures)
Cell Source: Any user-provided cells or organoids: primary, iPSC-derived, cell lines, etc.
Multiple Cell Types: Yes (co-cultures, multi-cell layering in the chip). Omi supports multi-inlet flow
Stromal Cells: Yes (fibroblasts, support cells in 3D). Omi’s gentle perfusion fosters complex constructs
Tissue-resident Immune: Yes, e.g. microglia in neural chips, Kupffer cells in liver chips
Circulating Immune: Yes (immune cells can be perfused to replicate vascular interactions)
Crosstalk (Multi-tissue): Possible by linking multiple Omi setups or multi-chamber chips in series
Air-Liquid Interface: Supported if the chosen chip has an ALI compartment. Omi manages perfusion in the fluid channels
Extracellular Matrix: Yes, 2D coatings or 3D hydrogels for advanced tissue. Omi ensures stable flow around them
3D Scaffold: Yes (spheroids, organoids, tissue slices). Omi continuously perfuses them, extends viability
Notable Features: All-in-one device with integrated pumps, sensors, software. Portable. Battery for microscope imaging. Automated multi-day runs
Plate/Format (Throughput): One chip at a time inside Omi, potentially moderate throughput with multiple Omi units in parallel
Max Culture Duration: Days to weeks. Omi’s stable environment fosters long-term culture (chronic toxicity, differentiation)
Readouts - Live Imaging: Yes, Omi is designed for easy microscope transfer (battery power). Real-time imaging possible
Readouts - Supernatant Sampling: Yes, via Omi’s fluidic lines. Automated or manual sample collection
Readouts - Cell Retrieval: Possible. Typically destructive flush or in situ analysis
Readouts - Whole Tissue: Chip-dependent. Often in situ confocal. Tissue removal if chip design allows
Readouts - TEER: Not built-in. External electrode approach if needed
Readouts - MEA: No integrated electrodes. Could combine with an MEA chip externally
Readouts - Integrated Biosensors: No embedded chemical sensors. Real-time flow/pressure sensors only
Dead Volume: Very low microfluidic footprint. Minimal tubing, quick media switching
Perfused: Yes, fully integrated microfluidic perfusion, stable flow rate, settable flow profiles
Gas Mix Controlled: No internal gassing. Typically used in an incubator or short-term outside (2-hour battery)
Real-time Microenvironment Control: Yes, can program dynamic flow, drug pulses, gradient creation, etc.
model_availability: Commercial product from Fluigent. Users provide their chosen organ chip or partner chip
